It doesn’t have to intrinsically be this, it only is so if it is, not if we see it to be this is -- or isn’t. Past the system of its existence is the value we give it. Material is is Is.

Part 2: No Things To Obsess Over

Section 1: Some Matter of Opinion

To stare at a wall and think it to be boring is projection. The only way in which anything is ever boring is to not have an active imagination. A lack of ability to either associate concepts or lack of ability to lose the control of the mind.

It seems wisdom and imagination seem to be interdependent at some level. Of course, one can’t be ‘wise’ with no imagination but one can have an imagination yet be unwise; however, one becomes more wise the more open to imagination they become. That is, if wisdom is to have knowledge and particularly good judgment, you can only judge things well by being open to judging something in the first place with a multitude of different perspectives -- the perspective which would come from the knowledge dimension of wisdom, which knowledge can only happen by some level of imagination to conjure that knowledge as one can’t learn anything without being open to learning first.

People can understand philosophy or math or physics, it’s just a matter of learning to think abstractly -- learning to connect things together. When does abstraction become concrete?

Polymathy only exists in the idea of understanding areas of expertise must always lead into knowing of what logically leads into another expertise. You cannot be a great scientist without being a philosopher,  you cannot be a great artist without understanding art. Subjects bleed, just like people. You can’t get to know a person without knowing of who inspired them. The problems of language strikes again.

The use of language is as important as anything else which one could consider practical or useful in any manner. Language is a way to describe the intrinsic, extrinsic, and systemic values of things. Language is formal axiology. Using the terms “good” and “bad” or “evil” gives that object talked about an intrinsic meaning relative to my perception of that thing. It becomes judge-worthy and presumptuous in its attachments. It’s harder to be relative. For example, you are not bad at mathematics, you do not understand how to formulate the answer for that abstract math claim. Your badness at math is not badness at all, it is relative to not understanding math as a chain and understanding the foundations of this chain to link the math together like another chain. It may be the need to look back at proofs or start again, but not “bad”. The words are too simple to use in any objective context. You may feel you are bad at math, and, subjectively, it is just as much of a valid claim to say this as if you were to say you are good at math.

Math itself is only a language by which to describe the science and logic of the Universe. The science of math is underlyingly not a language itself only that which already is logically accessible but not coherently explained. Mathematics provides the explanation to this logical phenomena by giving us a means to communicate it. The methodology by which we discern maths isn’t linguistically understandable, possibly, however, and this may be the flaw of mathematics is that it is, to our understanding, irreducibly complex -- but classically, it is just as it is -- unwavering, nonsensical and only rational. Which the rationality gives it sense. The logic of math exists by just the mathematics of logic itself. It is granted.

Science and philosophy, despite our best efforts, holds ground in interpretations of things. This is not an inherently bad thing. The more we wish to strive for objectivity only, the longer we neglect the importance that comes with subjectivity. A lack of factual assertion is not a lack of reason but of fact; reason can exist inside subjective domain as much as we perceive pure reason in objectivity.

Why would someone be anti-science and is it ever a good thing? This delves into the concept of being anti-anything. When is it necessary? To some degree, we must all be closed to be open in that regard, we do have to distance ourselves from that which we perceive to be negative.

To seek answers to think by only seeking out another viewpoint is not entirely sound to making informed decision on what may be the correct viewpoint, too. You must also consider yourself for a moment and examine what you think of this viewpoint based on previous knowledge and the validity of it based on the arguments themselves for such a belief and why such a belief would be believed first. However, don’t also only consider your opinion; without being experienced with this other viewpoint and the viewpoint of which you hold, you will conform to your own biases regardless of realization. You are not infallible, and in fact more likely to be than to not. The truth of how we learn is social and personal, and simultaneously not. But the truth that must completely exist becomes universally true, despite the social nature of gathering truth. The creative nature of it as well.
All creative thoughts must also be original thought. As, if not original, then that must mean that the thoughts were never connected by you. It may have been done before, but if your brain connected ideas together, that is then original creativity. Of course, proving this is impossible, therefore, to state something as unoriginal is, too, unoriginal. Unoriginal in the sense that you are connecting this something to something which you also had perceived earlier as not being original.

It is very odd that ‘thinking outside the box’ is a societally valuable trait. However, in order to think outside the box, one must entertain most thought but not believe in them, and even if they understand a thought to be perhaps incorrect or against a value they have reasoned, realize that there is always room for the case this different view is a matter of someone else’s perspective and not out of a perceived evilness. It is then we must attempt to reach  the level of the other there. You have to get higher to get low to the ground. [I’m still waiting on being able to understand both the low and high, relative to me, of course.]

The only thing we need more in life than trees are more trees.
A society which sees the arts as something beyond them and important yet actively condemns them. This is why the artist is seen as pretentious and the stereotype of the misunderstood artist happens, because the artist has understood full expression is the only kind of real expression. Repression of oneself becomes easily a repression of others. The more one hides from themselves, the harder they are to love. Because who they are shows not through theirself. This is why people who can see the true selves of others have some sort of gift, it’s not merely looking for the good in people as anyone can do that. It is an instinctual thing, perhaps too easily seeming as metaphysical. Something mystical and postmodern.

Luck as physically understood: Luck is a matter of an accidental probabilistic outcome in which one gets lucky, not a physical manifestation of something metaphysical happening - at least, not in the way in which we think so. The probability of some thing is metaphysical, beyond our physical perception, but the outcome is physical. A sophist would ask at what point does the metaphysical become physical, to which the wise man understands the question implies that happens. It is only illusory, not something which really happens. We cannot say that happens as we cannot yet say the metaphysical happens. It clear that luck is something that happens, coincidence is easily perceptible as just an outcome of probability in this dimension.

There’s an odd circular irony in the complete rejection of postmodern thought. In rejecting postmodernism, one falls victim to that which postmodernism first criticized: taking things for granted. That, rejection is something which must be granted out of the fact of postmodernism’s having the capability to become nihilism. Like sadness is to happiness, sincerity of thought can only first come by the deconstruction of it, and the modernism of this then forms a reconstruction of this new thought. Past the post, we enter a metamodernism, one which understands the sincerity of both modernism and postmodernism. Modernism takes things for granted, the postmodern then had to question, confuse, and befuddle the modernist into going “maybe I am wrong.” After postmodernism, one must decide to succumb to the nihilism that is easy to fall into or to create new values. At the heart of the struggle of living is the uncertainty of values, postmodernism exposes that the truth behind these values we have are no more true than another’s, but the conclusion, post-postmodern, is to understand that we must then take things as granted. [I think there is a systemic dismantling of objectivism which happens throughout history. (Postmodernism, atheism, anarchism, epistemic anarchy, anti-realism). Not only did Einstein reveal the universe is relative, but philosophically, everything is relative to another thing. We all think relatively. Systemic “transempiricism” is what is happening societally, duh. This is the radicalization of the absence of something and deciding upon it as being relative when a value or tradition has been logically compromised or dismantled.]

Nothing matters. This is a relief. To the uncreative, this is trap: “What now?”, he would say. But he doesn’t say this as an uncreative person doesn’t exist. There is no person incapable of connecting things. If he is to exist, he’s died already. In some sense, this would be eugenics by creativity. Which, well, doesn’t happen. With nothing mattering, we can create our own lives. Mirror the lives of heroes, remix their goodness into something better. If you don’t write anything down you’ll just have thoughts which go nowhere and die. How does it feel to be a murderer of thought, you Nazi?

An artist only dies when he realizes he no longer has something to share with the world and, also, nothing to gain from the world. It doesn’t matter the popularity of the work or of whether he physically died because he still lives in his work. The only way to live, then, is to make. If you cannot make, you cannot live. Which, then, all humans live. All humans and perhaps most, or even all, animals have the capacity to live. Just the perception of the existence of that capacity evaporates by either a lack of support or a lack of ability to find oneself out of something confining them to their current state of living -- to put this energy into uncreative, uncritical things.

If an artist can only talk about art and not of anything else, then we are doomed. We are doomed to continue not connecting the things together to form a better understanding of the world. If we cannot understand the interconnectedness of any subject, we become dogmatic in that area believing it to be the highest form of life or of expertise.

There is no point to be educated in art when you are not pushed to make art yourself. If you’ve not made art, there is nothing to gain from learning of any arts in school. The biggest problem is the false attribution of positivity. We can not say with certainty which art is not art, as all that is art is that which we attribute to it. Now, we can determine what art belongs into a certain category and say whether it is, to us, good or bad art. But all bad art is still nonetheless art. There is such a good thing as bad philosophy and good philosophy. Good Science and bad science. [The problem of a medium to a child should never be the advocacy of banning that art but only to introduce art contrary to it. Maybe.]

Leave works unfinished; not out of laziness but because there is always something to add. Add, add, add. Knowledge comes in snippets. You don’t get vast amounts of knowledge from lecture, you get it from conjecture. This is why we’ve continuously shortened our language. Attention is rapid, let’s adapt. The audience must be patient to understand.

We have to understand nothing to understand something because something is contingent on nothingness, just as any duality. Technology could maybe run on nothing eventually. What is needed is a soft heart, softness of natural being rooted in experience. When one is not in nature, one is not in tune with himself any longer. Primitivism is necessity, but so is progression to civilization. Real civilization can only come through the understanding of nature. Civilization does not imply capitalism, it implies socialism -- personal and universal attachment to nature. As not only are we the universe but the universe is us. If we cannot accept this fact, we cannot accept any part of reality. More than the obsession with nothing, one becomes nothing. I become nothing. Nature is all, nothing else.

Section 2: Loosening By Losing

To not lose control of oneself, of the mind in particular, out of being in control of oneself is ironically a lack of control in oneself. You cannot understand control without having lost it before. If you do not allow yourself to become lost, lost in a matter of freeing, you will always remain lost.

[There’s an uncanny loneliness which comes with not actually being alone -- in the sense of being able to think by yourself. Aloneness which is accompanied by some commodity, a commodity which gives the illusion of feeling a person’s presence. Through a screen. Through a plastic or glass under which is thousands of pixels aligning to form images quick enough to where it is fluid and simulates a realness. An aloneness which is the realization you have no one around you -- no one you connect to on a deep level, that is. No one, even if not a deep connection, who feels new. No spontaneity of living. Of going out.

Because, it’s hard to go. Contemplating just whether I should take the bus to the park. The only time to go anywhere being when one says we will go do something after a long period of me not showering and remaining “alone” with the screen. Even writing this is a task, but it has to come out in some form or I will become emotionally unhealthy -- more emotionally unhealthy, that is. Writing this, still, though fast, feels hard. Hard to understand. I’ve read on loneliness, have experienced before.

It is the point at which no hug is needed, no sympathy is needed. What is only needed is a sense of freedom past only feeling free in my mind. My spiritual life, my life of learning, is rich now. In dying poor, I die rich. If I were to die rich, I die poor. But what of my physical life? My romantic life? My sex life? My friendships? Who is there anymore? Fucking lonely. Terrible self-pity to a degree that this pity makes me feel less lonely yet simultaneously aware of the crippling loneliness of my days.]

The company of strangers after periods of loneliness helps one realize the beauty of every person.

Aloneness produces the best ideas in the same way loneliness produces a better appreciation for people. Too much aloneness produces a lack of a critical view of one’s ideas; too much loneliness turns into resentment -- and if already sociopathic, fuel for revenge.

Music is therapy in always the sense that it is never the case you look for, or listen to music which is not expressing what you feel, want to feel, or want not to feel. Not even lyrically, but instrumentally.

I lack the executive function to go somewhere. I recognize I need a change of pace. I need a new place. But the only new place and pace I remain to find new is just headspace and headspace may help, but not in actual spacing. I’ve lost the ability to feel okay. The only okay is passive, as a means to say “sure, I probably know this. I won’t act on this most likely.” The only okay is one of ambivalence, I no longer understand what is “okay”. I feel good. I feel. That is it. I just feel something. Something which permits me to keep going. A feeling that is quite describable, actually.

It seems we all have some form of executive dysfunction in which we do understand that something is right, such as it must be logically reasoned that the act of being lazy begets more laziness despite there also being an importance to laziness as well. This is also, of course, dependent on how well something is explained and to explain things in a manner completely reasonably simple to another is more of a gift of understanding something rather than of conceptual liability where the explanation is hard to break up again into steps. Everything is a whole part of a part of a of a whole and to grasp this notion is dependent on explaining that things are complexly reducible but this does not necessitate that this is easily perceptible. Property is a whole part of a part of the whole of politics which politics is a whole part of a part of the whole of human and nature interactions. All must be, however, explained sufficiently.

It seems that those who are shown complete compassion forget how compassion works. At a certain level, there is always the feeling of having been sabotaged by someone and the continuation of it if one is ever to ask for help, or even learn how to ask for help. Help is a mud-stained topic for those who were shown immense compassion before in their life to a degree of not knowing how to interact with those who do not share the same level of compassion. It is too much empathy, empathy for seemingly no good reason; to take on another person completely where, then, both become helpless and love together -- both only living by having not physically died yet, both still more vegetables than a tomato is not. Both rationalizing why they are still here. Why they must still be here in this big mess of a world, of a situation. Stuck in the fishbowl, of course. But, rather, stuck in the miniature castle in the fishbowl. It’s not as if the fish does not know how to come out, it’s not as if the fish is scared of what is out there, it is out of a lack of getting from point A to point B, a lack of executive action. To execute things is not in the resume of the prey. The prey can’t help but be the prey. He can try as he must, train with who he will, but the only thing he can truly do in life is to minimize his suffering. To feel less targeted, less of just some byproduct to the world. The prey could get along with the predator if both didn’t feel the necessity to view each other as such for the sake of food. Humans are prey and predator, just lesser so. Predatory in the hypermasculinity of how we associate -- a degrading of anything which could perhaps be even remotely homosexual or just not heterosexual. The predator hunts the predator to other prey for humans, really.

It’s easy to become disconnected from reality in the absence of physicality. Rothko’s works look boring on a phone screen. You don’t get the same perspective and experience you do otherwise being in person. You don’t get the same grandness of scale and immersion to watch a movie on your phone comparable to the theater. It’s easy to say art is boring because one is not looking at it in person. If anything, the view art is boring is more boring that any possibly boring art itself. It’s a tired notion people have uttered for decades. There’s a difference between seeing a bed of flowers and experiencing it.

There is a lack of personability to phone conversations, yet it also seems quite personal to you and who you are on the phone with because it is a mutual exchange. But personal interaction is also very physical in a lot of senses, experience is everything, and to hear the person you are talking to is only a small part of the experience. Not to mention the smell of them, the distance between you and them and how openly you perceive them in relation to when you are interacting with them; the perception of how they respond, how they wish to be proactive and initiate or continue the dialogue of the phone conversation. Phone conversations are great to hear, to give to the imagination of what that person was -- or is like by how you’d perceive them in person.

Be your own friend. We are all fundamentally lonely. Our mortality, relative to our input, controls us more than we control it. But, while the rate at which mortality can be controlled can be disputed, one thing isn’t: no one other than yourself controls this.

The intention may mean well behind a certain truth but no truth bears resemblance of a truth not given truthfully. Even if true, have you still just bought into it? What is the point of believing something if not knowing whether or not it may be true?

Not wishing to have friends is just a momentary lie to oneself to ease the pain of lacking true meaningful friendship which we all need. Only a fool believes they can always be alone. Cooperation is the root of the best of human endeavors, cooperation rooted in the understandable sense of the self and the selves of others.

One’s replicability does not matter in terms of one’s existentiality, only the difficulty of replicability. If one is hard to be replaced, one has done well. If one is easy to replace, one has wasted life. Perhaps the only goal of life, relative to others’ lives, is just to be hard to replace -- hard to be copied.

We all want someone to hug us and tell us that things, despite how hard they will be, will be okay. This is an extension on treating others as you should want to be treated. You want that, to be heard. To be understood. Why not be that person to another? Be understanding. In order to improve life, your own life as well, you must sacrifice a part of your life for others. No one lives your life but you, but you can’t live your life only without also not living for others.

Perhaps I am only able to feel free as a result of living in a constricting world. Perhaps it is the case that my freedom is dependent on being for something else rather than being from another. As, is it then freedom if you are not the acting cause to continue that momentum from? If you can’t get more than from to for, how does one ever expect to be free? How does one ever expect to live? This is why wisdom is by lacking. If you lack freedom, you must seek it. If you lack anything, identifying that which you lack happens and causes you to them seek it out. I may be free now, but I could be free-er.

Not free from what, free for what? To be free from is the maintaining of the idea that one was in shackles in the first place, rather, it should be that you controlled your situation. As in, what are you now free for? In order to be free, ironically, you must seek a necessary dependence on doing something or the hedonistic experience of slavish “freedom” swings into nihilism of life quickly.

True liberation should come with being free from the oppressor and not having to stoop to the level the oppressor has. Pacifistic by and of nature

Wisdom is often characterized as gaining understanding from experience. Wisdom, too, can be a gaining of understanding from a lack of experience, a lack of having or doing something which must compel one to understand the importance of that thing on a social and personal level. Wisdom, therefore, has to be all-encompassing, all knowing, to a degree. There is luxury in necessity, not necessity in luxury. Visa Virtue.

Section 3: Emotionalizing Rationality

How do we justify mockery? Is mockery ever justifiable?

When should one hate? Should one hate animals for invading their property in some capacity which is an irritation for the person? Of course, not just dislike, but hate. Any person with a sense of self is going to dislike this happening, but should one hate? For example, rats. Rats are cute creatures despite the disease they carry and the mess they leave.

Do we not wish to be the equal to animals? To be equal is not a usurpation of our rights nor an advancement of theirs, only a matter of understanding. How can one be with another living creature and look down on it? How can one look in contempt? The further we lose love for animals, for any living thing, is the further we move from ourselves. We are animals. Animals are people, too. A person speaks to the effect of who we call our own, too, and all is our own. Spiders are people, rats are people. Do they attack out of maliciousness or out of seeing you as a threat? We are as close to cheetahs as cheetahs are to giraffes; both are animals and so are we. We are not a complete difference from them. There are many sentient animals, many animals capable of reasoning and sentience. To make problems only human is a problem of isolation; this is ego problem -- an echo chamber.

The only ethical outcome is to properly understand self-interest or selfishness, but such ethical standard comes from the basis of others’ too. The relationship is to be interpersonal, which is why the theory of selfishness and selflessness is wrong. The ethical way to behave -- or to begin and end is in the reassurance of others by being assured in oneself -- to affirm your life, not on others or yourself, but on that which you can do. The money gained, the praise earned, the assurance of self from things you do is not the real outcome, it is the realization of the spreading of yourself to others -- to make an impact on something other than what is readily available. The ego should develop but on the basis of the contribution to a greater society.

Complete selflessness is just what it is, self-less, lessening the affirming of the self by only the focus upon others.

How could a friend ever be a friend if ‘he judges and looks at you as lesser than by admitting things which make you vulnerable? How could a person ever be a person? How, as a human, could one ever disregard or judge another while knowing of going through hard times? He is human, you are human. Humans suffer, whether continually or continuously. Not empathizing, not showing the empathetic compassion you would need, too, when vulnerable, is inhumane. If one has friends who are not family, they are not friends, they’re just friends.

The only reason one finds in the rationalization of hurting another is in finding that person to be below human or animal, that person is somehow a scum which must be rid. This, too, only happens when coupled with a lack of perspective, as humans make mistakes. The goal should be to make the human remorseful of what they have done, not to punish them for doing what they have done. Thus, when is punishment justified? We all have this inclination, not of love, but something beyond us to help another. In the most rudimentary sense, this is, of course, altruism.

Altruism, collectively, cannot be altruistic if another must depend on the altruism on another to survive and thus becomes dependent on the altruism. Dependence lacks the humanity of us, we must be interdependent. Altruism can only be altruistic if the outcome results in a net positive effect for those involved. The more you want, the less you get. Get out of giving.

Attachment and connection are very different. Emotions can be rational and the foundation of our emotions are rational, really. [I realized too late the importance of connection, and despite having connection over the line, it is impersonal to a degree.]

The real growth that takes place in any sort of betterment of the self has to deal not with doing things by oneself, but first having the ability to. To cognitively lack the ability to help oneself not suffer exorbitantly, help from another to get to the point of being able to help oneself is necessary. Thus cognitive lack of ability can be from something as rooted as apathy to something as observant as retardation; both, and any other way in which one lacks, is not a fault of the person. This is where psychological conservatism can become almost sociopathic, in which one does not realize that not every one simply has the means to help themselves. We are not born perfectly social or capable, and even if one is, it can be shaped to become a learned behavior of helplessness to the point of being utterly helpless to themselves and need to guidance to get help or to be able to even receive help. Behavior is part nature, mostly nurture. The point of helping another is not to give them some path you are taking but giving them the ability to be free for something, not from. Freedom from leaves something that is then filled with a desire, virtue or vice, but to be free for something is true freedom. One should not be suggested “Hey, you should be an astronaut”, it should be “Do you want to be an astronaut?”. Suggestion to others is counterintuitive and confines them as a freedom from, openness of ability -- openness of question, leads to giving the ability to another to forge a path. By suggesting, we limit.

Sometimes, someone holding your hand really is all you need to get started. Some are too selfish to realize this, even when asked. If one cannot muster the ability to even want to do a thing, what makes you think they can just get up and do that thing. All of us need help, sometimes it is our duty to our fellow person to help them when we realize they need help and can’t ask for it. And sometimes, it is necessary to let them fall because what may be perceived as falling to you may not be falling to them. Peace is relative. Those who are not free unwittingly try to enclose those who are when they recognize their freedom.

A way in which people think binarily is that people seem to think it is either your fault or the fault of someone else. Either that you are the product of your reality or your reality is the product of you. And neither is false, but just one is not true either. Nature gives way to nurture and the phenomenon of nurture itself happens because you make it happen, too, but out of the problems arisen. By this case, it becomes reprehensible to consider someone else reprehensible without an understanding of that person; without an understanding of why that person believes.

The smartest people can, too, be the most superficial. A lot of them, despite their smarts, look at others on their superficial value or the way they perceive the other person -- that because they are loud, or obnoxious, or do not talk about deep concepts about the universe, they are somehow devoid of smartness or not worthy of our time. We can always gain to learn something from anyone; the mark of an intellectually mature person -- not the mark of just an intellectual person -- is their willingness to understand that everyone can be as smart as they themselves are -- or smarter. But other factors, perhaps even biological, prevent them from doing so or to even pursue doing so. This is why altruism is the necessity of nature: to nurture. To nurture the possible intellectual growth of our peers, too, and not to only judge them, but to be perceptive and understand the parts where learning can take hold. You cannot only teach them, them learning teaches you too.

This is what I realize with everything I do, watch, say, read, or listen to:
There is never something not to learn. Even if you know the outcome, it is best to widen your area of understanding by discovering the other side of the issue. Even if your beliefs remain confirmed, what you should learn is to not be complacent to what you have learned, there is the plausibility that what you learned will be something that you’ve heard before but framed differently than what was framed previously.

It would be foolish to engage with someone who would have no capacity to understand you as that then becomes a waste of your time. That engagement belongs to someone else to make who is closer to their level. But this is not a hierarchical association of intelligence or awareness but of an association of whom is along their path at a similar time as the one who you would not be able to reach. This is not to say that in relation you are the superior, only to say that you two speak two languages and therefore need time for the other to go through translations to get to where you are, or perhaps that inverse of that situation in which you must be the one to get translations. As this is a case of becoming a monster as well, if you cannot speak the language -- a language not contingent on culture but of personability -- then you will succumb to loss.

Addiction implies impunity, beyond someone’s control. If you are addicted, you are not yourself fully. You need to be reformed from the addiction.

Suicide as a permanent solution to a temporary problem is not a complete understanding of suicide, as all things are temporary and so is life. The impermanence of everything is all that really is permanent, what is the qualifier to place permanence above temporariness when the inevitable solution to living is to die anyhow? Life would be impermanent anyhow and what is the reason to view suicide as selfish just by ending one’s life by one’s own hands to stop living, as, in order to kill oneself you have to have died already. What is the selfishness in ending one’s suffering?? In the case in which life is insufferable, it is best to end it when one has been fulfilled, when one can no longer balance living with suffering. Suicide is not selfish always, nor is the argument to it being a permanent solution a sound argument against suicide as of course the permanent quality of ending one’s life has to come from understanding that one’s life is temporary anyhow. Should we then wish that we use temporary solutions to solve temporary problems? No, we should wish to use a permanent one. One which extinguishes the problem and that is the logic of suicide.

Codependent people in relationships are caused by parents who depend on their child to vent to emotionally. That is, if it is one-sided or both have no one else to rely upon to vent. Codependence is birthed from low self-esteem.

What is included in falling in love is also the falling apart of life. If one loves something so much, it can become obsessive; it is the same area of the brain. That which one loves, one is also obsessed with. When you are obsessed, you neglect everything else. You neglect necessities. This also leads into why something can grow from this deep love and obsession: an understanding of the fragility of all things, we must not really place our values hierarchically. All values have to be not conviction based and have to be both philosophically abstract and practical.

We are all made up of the ideas of others. This does not change the ideas themselves, only that the ideas of others make us. Doesn’t lessen our individuality. If you can’t defend the idea don’t mention it to others until it has some perceivable truth behind it.

Section 4: Nothing Values

The truth I have found for myself in the concept of living -- in the scale of what cosmology has taught us, the scale the values by us has taught us -- is that we must always have to find something greater than us. And, perhaps out of my experience of the lack of understanding and the bias that must come with that, the truth I have come with is something I find complex but very simplistic in what makes the universe obviously only so bearable: love. Love is the only way in which to be free yet simultaneously chained, freedom is a contradiction of value, love is, too. The universe, in this way, contradicts itself, and life must contradict itself, too. In order to appreciate the small, we must think large. In order to notice beauty, we must have seen that which is not beautiful. This is simple, but it implies much about us and our place in how we should and can be as people of the World. The goal is to express, to love. But I’m not satisfied with love. Love, as understood by many philosophers before, transcends us. Like consciousness, it is clearly physically manifested, but it is also metaphysical. Not only love of another but love of something. Love of art, love of science.

The problem with love is you cannot fall in moderation, it is a hard fall. You break your legs, every bone in your body. Then probably your heart, somehow, out of falling too hard. You should have at least skid on the rocks when you fell, but you fall straight down. How’s the weather down there? Probably, lonely.

The root of any and all relationships is a matter of trust. You trust your dog not to bite you. You trust your father not to kill you. You trust your government to represent you. And this is the fault of government, it is so personalistic that it misses the personalities of all who inhabit it. The state is untrustworthy, as it clearly betrays your trust. You trust it will let you harm yourself; it will not let you, even if such harm leads to eventual well-being.

That which is permanent and perfect must be imperfect and impermanent. That this thing must be able to be scrutinized and falsifiable and, if so, cannot last forever. A new perspective, or larger a new paradigm, will come after continually. The change of things is the only thing permanent which simultaneously negates the permanence as change is a process of impermanence, replacement of revolutionization.

As humans, we long for perfection. Perfection of thought, perfect sports team, perfect nation, perfect family, perfect friends, perfect self, perfect god. That something, in order for us to live must be perfect at some level. The sooner we accept the imperfections of all things, the sooner we realize the lack of objectivity of action, the impermanence. Imperfection and impermanence are the principles to live. There is no immediate harm in wanting perfection. There is harm in not recognizing perfection is naturally unattainable. The perfect can only be that which is imperfect. And the permanent can only be that which is impermanent. Love dies when our conscious dies. But the permanence of love is by having loved in the first place, not by it existing beyond us. It does not. Past our existence, our love no longer exists. Only a new love, by the discovery of our love, can exist. A new love which is not our love, but it is love, thus making love permanent. You must think of what truths you can make not which ones you can believe. The thesis of life is making a new one, new values much note that the nothings we take as granted.

The only way in which to become down to Earth is to look for something greater than your Earthly perspective; only then would you even be down to Earth. You can only get high by starting low. Thus, man is not an end in himself, he is the beginning of another. Something greater than man. This does not mean man is without worth, only that there is always something greater, which is proven by the necessity for us to go and grow; we cannot grow by only seeing us as an end. To assume an end is to assume the end, the end of the progression of man. Man clearly is able to progress and ‘he should be better ‘men. Apes led to us, this does not undermine the value of apes, this enhances it as it showed the adaptability of ape to man. And man, therefore, must adapt, too, to become any sort of nu.

Are you telling me there is nothing else to do other than to consume? Consuming is just an excuse to pretend to care. Amortal.

There is little inherently wrong with consuming things, but consumption becomes a problem in the wake of not creating. If one is to only consume and not create, ‘he is a shell of a human -- a body -- and can only live, or really, feel they can only live, by consuming. That creating is foolish and does nothing. In order to create, one must consume. Otherwise, that which you consume is uncritical and you believe what you hear, you don’t challenge the World at large, you take it in, doing nothing of it. Eventually getting misinformed to the point of believing yourself to be Right, a slow, dissociation and psychosis -- a dissociation of the world to the point of attributing existence to a nothing, a nothing value.

Everyone thinks. No thinking person wants to be happy, just content. A neutral state of being, one where we can observe our current situation of where we are with fresh eyes is what is needed in life. Happiness assumes life is a positive; life is a neutral which leans easily towards negatives. If there is a scale of quality of life, complete positivity is simultaneously negative, positive for oneself negative for others. A small level of positivity is needed. Emotion swings easily and life is so full in itself, the state if a neutral emotional state of life is fuller than what we perceive as optimism to be the fullest full.

[I do not wish to be happy, I wish to be stable -- to be content. Happiness prevents one from completing tasks just as sadness does. Extremes of any emotion are never something which we should strive towards. We should strive towards moderation of our emotions; complete control.]

The only real knowledge which must exist is just the eventual ability to express any idea as being obvious. Which becomes the point of any philosophy, and methodology to entertaining some truth: explaining reality obviously, explained not with conviction (as there must always be doubt otherwise the method has failed) but with understanding, deep understanding of a given topic. Understanding to a degree that the perceived “practical” seems impractical by the negation of that supposed truth with the substitution of the real truth. The practical is what holds one from any truth and simultaneously holds one from any universal truth all that same, as you can’t be universal and not be rejected by most despite the contradictory nature of such a declaration. It’s not that the truth sets you free, it is the truth forces one to have nothing else in life but to be free -- whatever those “free” and “true” are. Freedom is nothing; freedom is a dead nothing as equality of outcome is: bankrupt with the illusion of truth. Freedom, nor liberty, are truth; the only thing which looks to be truth is nothing. Nothing is fixed, true nothing remains fixed, Jimbo.

Anything has the ability to be conversed about.

Permanent Imperfection and Perfect Impermanence.

Nothing values are not values which don’t exist but are so shallow they are barely considered value, rather just an easy, unquestioned belief. Something value is a new value, a value which actually has basis, truth or not.

Nothingness is the key to the Universe, as most of the universe is effectively “nothing”.

The best way in which to approach something is with a lack of presupposing something exists or is true before the examination of it. We should all begin our scientific investigation not assuming we are in a period of order, but of chaos and that this order must be found through not the building of hierarchical association of ideas but by the building of understanding. Though the building of understanding may be contingent on a hierarchical realism of the world anyhow due to our perception. Or it may be the case that our perception is right within any dimensional reference point but we have metaphysical aspirations.

That seems to be the only way in which we can ever understand something: by the understanding of nothing first to get to something. You cannot understand something without understanding nothing. If you understand nothingness, not nothing, you understand.Embed

title: Sometimes
lyrics:
The Return of Doctor Mysterio LyricsWe look at a comic book's blank panel that says 'later that night', then down from the night sky to an American street. A New York yellow cab passes by Joe's Pizza, then we look up the fire escape and into a young man's window. Comic books are by the bed, along with his spectacles, and he is dreaming of a time when -
Young Grant's bedroom
The swoosh of a large pendulum outside the window wakes a boy. He coughs.
DOCTOR: Hey!
Grant puts on his spectacles, turns on his flash light and goes to the window as the Doctor swings by, upside down.
DOCTOR: Hello there! Ah, hello!
Grant opens the window.
YOUNG GRANT: Hello?
DOCTOR: Hello!
YOUNG GRANT: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: I was setting a trap.
YOUNG GRANT: A trap?
DOCTOR: On your roof.
YOUNG GRANT: What happened?
DOCTOR: I tried it out.
YOUNG GRANT: How?
DOCTOR: Accidentally.
The Doctor stops swinging. Grant sneezes.
DOCTOR: Bless you.
YOUNG GRANT: Thanks.
DOCTOR: What's your name?
YOUNG GRANT: Grant.
DOCTOR: Hello, Grant. What floor is this?
YOUNG GRANT: Sixty.
DOCTOR: Ah!
The rope and electrical cable around his ankles begin to part and fray.
DOCTOR: Would it all right if I came in?
YOUNG GRANT: I'll have to ask my mom.
Grant shuts the window on the Doctor's fingers.
DOCTOR: Ow!
YOUNG GRANT: Mom, wake up.
The Doctor tries to sonic the sash window open, then Grant opens it again.
DOCTOR: Oh!
YOUNG GRANT: Mom says you can come in. You're expected.
DOCTOR: Expected? Argh!
The rope and cable have finally parted. The Doctor heaves himself back up over the window sill and collapses on the floor. Grant puts a glass of milk and plate of cookies down for him.
DOCTOR: Sorry, did you say I was expected?
YOUNG GRANT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Who did you say I was?
YOUNG GRANT: I told her I saw an old guy at the window. sneezes
DOCTOR: Ho-ho-ho-ho. Merry Christmas, Grant!
He eats a cookie and browses Grant's collection of Superman comics. Grant returns to his bedroom.
YOUNG GRANT: Mom and Dad are asleep now. I can get you back on the roof. I know the way.
DOCTOR: Shh.
YOUNG GRANT: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: Take a look at that picture.
Clark Kent talking to Mrs Olsen.
YOUNG GRANT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Now this one. Superman Take a good, long look. It takes a moment to see it.
YOUNG GRANT: See what?
DOCTOR: Superman and Clark Kent are one and the same person.
YOUNG GRANT: Are you serious?
DOCTOR: Yeah. Look, I drew specs on Superman.
YOUNG GRANT: Everyone knows they're the same person.
DOCTOR: Well, Lois Lane doesn't, and she's a reporter.
Stairs
DOCTOR: Why did they call him Spider-Man? Don't they like him?
YOUNG GRANT: He was bitten by a radioactive spider, and guess what happened?
DOCTOR: Radiation poisoning, I should think.
Roof
YOUNG GRANT: No, he got special powers.
DOCTOR: What, vomiting, hair loss and death? Fat lot of use. Hey! What do you think?
YOUNG GRANT: That looks
DOCTOR: I know.
YOUNG GRANT: Cheap.
A pile of bits of metal and various styles of television antennae and satellite dishes.
DOCTOR: Oh, shut up! Got a cold there, Grant?
YOUNG GRANT: I always get a cold at Christmas.
DOCTOR: Me too. Or an invasion.
He hands Grant a glass of water.
YOUNG GRANT: Where did you get that from?
DOCTOR: My pocket.
YOUNG GRANT: How do you keep a glass of water in your pocket?
DOCTOR: Skills. Now hush, I've got a lot of work to do. Take this.
A small red glowing octahedron.
YOUNG GRANT: Who are you?
DOCTOR: The Doctor.
YOUNG GRANT: Yeah, but who are you?
DOCTOR: The Doctor.
YOUNG GRANT: Which one, though? There's lots of doctors.
DOCTOR: The one. I'm the main one. The original. I started it. They're all based on me. Now everyone who wants to sound clever calls themselves Doctor. Bandwagon!
YOUNG GRANT: In a comic book, you know what you'd be called? Doctor Mysterio.
DOCTOR: Oh, I like that. Doctor Mysterio! I'll have that. Nearly ready.
YOUNG GRANT: What is it?
DOCTOR: Well, in terms that you would understand? Sorry, there aren't any. It's a, it's a, it's a, it's a time-distortion equaliser thingy.
YOUNG GRANT: A what?
DOCTOR: Well, there's been a lot of localised disruption here in New York, so, er, my fault, actually. Hopefully this will make it all calm down.
YOUNG GRANT: I don't understand.
DOCTOR: Do you know what a lightning conductor is?
YOUNG GRANT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Well, it's not like that.
YOUNG GRANT:  I thought you were setting a trap.
DOCTOR: I was, to protect this. I don't want anyone turning it off, or stealing it for a Christmas tree.
YOUNG GRANT: But it looks like a Christmas tree.
DOCTOR: Of course it does, it's science. Do you want to turn the lights on?
YOUNG GRANT: Can I?
DOCTOR: Go on. It's Christmas Day.
YOUNG GRANT: What do I do?
DOCTOR: Ah! Right, you put this into this, and you flick all those little switches on.
YOUNG GRANT: Nothing's happening.
DOCTOR: Yeah, because now we get to the cool bit. Come here. Do you see that little door there? Pop it open. Now we turn on the lights. Pop the gemstone right in there.
Six sets of wires going into a circular holder.
YOUNG GRANT: What gemstone?
DOCTOR: The gemstone that I gave you. Pop it right in there.
YOUNG GRANT: sotto That was a gemstone?
DOCTOR: Well, it's more than just a gemstone, it's also like a kind of on-board computer. Come here. Can you see, can you see that little yellow star at the end of that curve? It comes from near there. Formed in the heart of a red hole and stabilised in pure dwarf star crystal. The gemstone is intuitive. It knows what you want and draws energy from the nearest star to make it happen. There's only four of them left in the universe. The Apocalypse Monks of the Andorax called this one the Hazandra, the Ghost of Love and Wishes. Okay, then, pop it in.
YOUNG GRANT: I thought it was medicine.
DOCTOR: What?
YOUNG GRANT: It looked like medicine.
DOCTOR: What have you done with it?
YOUNG GRANT: Well, you gave me medicine and a glass of water, and you said you were a doctor. I thought it was for my cough.
There is a red glow in Grant's chest.
DOCTOR: Oh! You swallowed it. You can't go round swallowing things. What age are you, 36?
YOUNG GRANT: Eight.
The Doctor runs the sonic screwdriver over him.
YOUNG GRANT: Am I going to get sick?
DOCTOR: No, no, no, no. Quite the opposite.
YOUNG GRANT: The opposite? What's the opposite?
Grant's feet have left the ground. The Doctor gently pushes him back down.
YOUNG GRANT: What happened?
DOCTOR: Nothing.
YOUNG GRANT: What's wrong with me?
DOCTOR: Well, you've got a cough and a slight case of levitation. Stay calm.
YOUNG GRANT: What happens if I don't stay calm?
The Doctor has to jump to grab the boy's legs.
DOCTOR: Oh! Don't panic.
YOUNG GRANT: What happens if I panic?
They zoom off into the night sky, screaming.
Nursery
A baby's crying is being relayed by a monitor. Grown up Grant wakes, puts on his spectacles and goes to the nursery.
GRANT: Oh, hey, you're all right. Hi, you're okay.
He picks up the baby.
GRANT: Yeah. Ssh-ssh-ssh-ssh! later, on the phone Hey, Mrs Lombard. No, don't worry, Jennifer's fine. She just woke up, but I'm going to put her back to sleep. No, it's okay, Mrs Lombard. It's what you pay me for. okay. Goodnight.
Top of the Empire State Building
DOCTOR: Grant, you need to concentrate.
YOUNG GRANT: What's happened to me?
DOCTOR: Intuitive crystal, plus too many comic books. The gemstone is giving you what it thinks you want. You're a superhero!
Harmony Shoal
A skyscraper with a rotating globe on top, with Harmony Shoal written where it ought to say Daily Planet. A press conference is closing.
BROCK: Any questions after today can be handled by Miss Shuster or Miss Siegel, who can be contacted on the e-mail addresses provided in your welcome pack. That's all we have time for, ladies and gentlemen. I hope you had a stimulating day, and maybe saw a little of what makes Harmony Shoal the foremost innovator in science and technology the world over. Like we always say, we're here to open your minds.
LUCY: Mister Brock, just one more question. I've been looking into your funding, and you seem to have a lot of benefactors for a research institute.
BROCK: The world is changing, Miss Fletcher. Science got sexy.
LUCY: Yeah, but your benefactors? I can't seem to find any of them.
BROCK: Very simple reason for that. I killed them all, buried them in my back yard.
Laughter.
LUCY: How big is your back yard, Mister Brock?
BROCK: At the last count, Wyoming.
More laughter.
BROCK: Now, if you good people will excuse me, this young lady will guide you to the exit.
NARDOLE: Mister Brock? Er, Mister Brock? Mister Brock? Mister Brock.
BROCK: Apparently we have one more question.
NARDOLE: Yes. Where is the little boys' room?
BROCK: I think you'll find the restrooms to the left, on your way out.
NARDOLE: No, not the restrooms, the little boys' room.
BROCK: If you successfully locate the restrooms, I think you'll find everything you need in there. Thank you all.
WOMAN: This way, ladies and gentlemen.
NARDOLE: I don't want a rest. If everyone's just having a rest, I might cause an incident.
Lucy looks across at a woman sweeping the floor. Meanwhile Brock goes to a man dabbing at his nose and getting a blue stain on his handkerchief.
BROCK: Doctor Sim, is there a problem?
SIM: It's the brains. There's something I need to show you. It's necessary.
Brock sees Lucy with the cleaner.
BROCK: Later. Meet me here at midnight.
SIM: Thank you, sir.
Midnight, Sim is sitting in front of one of a few rows of computer screens ranged to the side of the main open area where the conference was held, and just behind the big corporate logo, when a hand grasps his shoulder and makes him jump.
SIM: Mister Brock. You startled me.
BROCK: Shall we?
SIM: Of course.
Lucy, dressed as a cleaner, watches them walk through reception, then follows. Nardole is also watching, and speaks into one of his duffel coat toggles.
NARDOLE: All clear.
Brain safe
A thick strongroom door opens and the lights come on to reveal a horseshoe arrangement of three shelves, all containing brains in glass cases.
BROCK: Well?
SIM: Look at them. You see nothing unusual?
BROCK: I see brains every place except here. Sim's head. These specimens were donated to this facility by our benefactors for a top-secret research project. A project which is not to be questioned, impeded, or in fact mentioned by any of the employees of the Harmony Shoal Institute. Even I don't have the clearance to know what's going on in here.
Lucy is eavesdropping.
SIM: But why?
BROCK: It's not your job to ask questions. Stick to science.
Sim's eye flickers sideways.
BROCK: Something wrong with your eyes?
SIM: Sir, the first time I came in here, I counted twenty four specimens. The second time I counted, there were thirty. Now there are thirty six.
BROCK: Well, I guess they've got the space.
SIM: You don't understand. There have been no deliveries. I checked it. Some of these brains, sir, they just... ..arrived.
Outside the Brain Safe
Lucy leans back to hear someone eating. The Doctor is snacking on sushi or more likely hosomaki.
DOCTOR: It's okay. I'm an intruder too. Yeah, I brought snacks. Mark of a pro. Keep listening.
Brain Safe
BROCK: Looks like a brain to me. Kind of blue, I guess,but that's the fluid, right?
SIM: Yes. That's the fluid. which is dribbling out of his nose. Tap the glass, sir.
BROCK: What'd you say?
SIM: Tap the glass, please.
Brock taps the glass, and two eyes appear between folds of the brain.
BROCK: What? What the hell is that? Is that a joke?
SIM: No sir, it's not a joke.
BROCK: It's got eyes! Look at them, they're like Sim's eyes flicker sideways again. They're like your eyes.
SIM: Yes sir, they are.
BROCK: Doctor Sim? What are you pointing at?
Sim points at a brain in an empty jar on the top shelf.
SIM: I'm pointing at Doctor Sim. Don't look so alarmed. We merely exchanged containers. You might call this a hijack.
Brock punches Sim, who grabs him by the throat, then throws him to the floor. Sim pushes the two halves of his head back together along the diagonal scar.
BROCK: What happened to you? I don't understand.
SIM: The same thing that is about to happen to you. I had a change of mind.
Sim leaves, closing the strongroom door behind him. Three doors slide up behind the shelves and three blank-faced figures in white surgical scrubs and masks step out.
BROCK: No, no, please, no! Let me out of here! What's happening?What are you doing?
One of the surgeons unscrews the lid of a brain jar.
Outside the restrooms
Sim finishes sealing the strongroom door and leaves. The Doctor taps Lucy with a chopstick and gestures for them to go the opposite way, down some stairs. The Tardis has parked herself on a mezzanine above the restrooms.
DOCTOR: Who are you?
LUCY: Lucy Fletcher, reporter from the Daily Chronicle. Hang on, why am I telling you the truth?
DOCTOR: Spooky, isn't it? Looking for a story?
LUCY: I think I just found one.
DOCTOR: Brains with minds of their own? No one will believe that. This is America.
LUCY: Who are you?
They go over to a map of the world with markers in it.
DOCTOR: Special Agent Dan Dangerous from Scotland Yard, Scotland. The Doctor for short. See, they've got institutes all over the world. And always in capital cities.
NARDOLE: Nope.
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, they are, see?
NARDOLE: New York's not a capital city,is it?
DOCTOR: sotto You don't need to point out the mistakes. That's not what you're for.
NARDOLE: Washington's got its own one, yeah.
The main lights come on.
SIM: I would call Security, but they might leave you alive. I do not want any awkward questions about the intruders I was forced to shoot for my own protection.
DOCTOR: Good plan. Here's another one. he turns his back on Sim. Go on. Tell them you shot us in the back in self-defence. We'll be laughing all the way to the slab.
Knocking nearby.
SIM:  Face me.
DOCTOR: Maybe not.
SIM: Face me now.
Knock, knock, knock.
SIM: What is that?
NARDOLE: It's not me.
LUCY: It sounds like
DOCTOR: Like someone knocking at a window.
LUCY: We're on the hundredth floor.
They all turn to look at the plate glass windows behind them. A masked man is standing there in mid-air.
LUCY: Oh, my God, he's real.
DOCTOR: Who's real?
LUCY: The Ghost.
DOCTOR: Who's the Ghost?
LUCY: Masked vigilante. But he's
DOCTOR: What?
LUCY: Super.
The Ghost snaps his fingers and the plate glass shatters. He glides inside.
GHOST: Mind if I come in?
SIM: Impressive. Those windows, like everything in this building, are built to withstand a blast equivalent to four nuclear explosions.
GHOST: Sorry about that. Would you like me to call a glazier?
SIM: Hmm.
Sim empties his gun clip into the Ghost, but they just bounce off. The Ghost brushes the final bullet of his G breast plate, then in a blink he is holding Sim up by the neck.
GHOST: Please understand, it's against my personal code to cause lasting harm to any individual.
He throws Sim against the map.
GHOST: However, light to moderate injury's fine.
NARDOLE: That was good.
GHOST: Hello. Was that man annoying you?
LUCY: You're real? I can't believe it, you're actually real.
GHOST: I'm afraid I am. I enjoy your column, Miss Fletcher.
LUCY: You read my column? You read? You're real and you read?
GHOST: Though I find the political bias in your paper's editorial not entirely to my taste.
LUCY: I'll pass that on.
GHOST: Thank you. Who are these gentlemen?
LUCY: They're, er. I don't actually know.
DOCTOR: This is my friend, Nardole.
NARDOLE: Hello, the Ghost.
DOCTOR: And I'm the Doctor.
GHOST: The Doctor. I thought we had lots of doctors. I'm the main one.
The Ghost gives a little nod then turns to Lucy.
GHOST: Can I give you a ride home?
LUCY: You have a car?
GHOST: No. He takes her in his arms. I hope you're okay with heights.
LUCY: I'm okay so far.
GHOST: Have a good evening, gentlemen.
He flies of into the night sky, Lucy screaming with delight.
NARDOLE: He seems nice.
DOCTOR: Grant.
Top of the Empire State Building
YOUNG GRANT: So I'm a superhero now?
DOCTOR: Well, once the gemstone is gone from inside you, you'll be back to normal. It will pass.
YOUNG GRANT: But how will it get out?
DOCTOR: Like I said, it will pass. Looking forward to that.
YOUNG GRANT: Are you sure?
DOCTOR: Of course I'm not sure. Nothing's ever sure. Just promise me one thing. For as long as you have these powers, you will never, ever use them.
YOUNG GRANT: Sure.
Street
GHOST: Is this the right building? They all look the same from up there.
LUCY: Yeah. Yeah, this is me, thanks.
GHOST: Well, I certainly hope this unpleasant experience hasn't put you off a career in journalism.
LUCY: Oh, no, no, no, not at all.
Something beeps from a pouch in the Ghost's cape. He turns to check a baby monitor.
GHOST: Sorry. Duty calls.
LUCY: Look at that. The Bat-Signal's an app now? What is it? Bank robbery? Hijack?
GHOST: Er, something like that. Excuse me.
He flies off.
LUCY: Go get 'em.
Nursery
Baby Jennifer is crying when the Ghost flies into his bedroom window, does a Wonder Woman twirl to change into mild-mannered Grant, puts on his spectacles then discovers that the crib is empty. The Doctor is cradling the baby.
DOCTOR: With great power comes great responsibility. No man worthy of the title leaves a baby alone.
GRANT: How did you find me?
DOCTOR: I tracked the gemstone inside you.
Apartment
They go through to the main living area, with kitchenette in the corner and a dining table, etc.
DOCTOR: Your powers, they don't belong in this world. They're an anomaly. You promised me you'd never use them.
GRANT: May I take her?
DOCTOR: She's yours?
GRANT: I'm hers. I'm her nanny.
DOCTOR: handing Jennifer over You're her nanny?
GRANT: Yeah, her nanny. You got a problem with that?
DOCTOR: No, no, it's just, well, okay, so you are a superhero and a nanny?
GRANT: Well, you've got to make a buck somehow. I mean, you don't get paid for saving people.
NARDOLE: Oh, you don't have to tell us. Here you go, nice and warm. And tasty.
Grant takes the baby bottle from Nardole, who then spots a toy to play with.
NARDOLE: Ooo, elephant.
GRANT: It's fine. It's a long-range baby-monitor. I can get back to this apartment quicker than most people can get to their kids' bedrooms.
DOCTOR: Grant, Grant, this is insane. Look, I'm me, the Doctor, and even I think this is insane.
NARDOLE: Even him.
GRANT: I can cope.
DOCTOR: Of course you can't. When do you sleep? When are you not on call? How complicated do you need your life to be?
The apartment door opens and closes. The Doctor and Nardole have nowhere to hide.
GRANT: Well, not as complicated as it's about to get. Er, we're in here, Mrs Lombard.
LUCY: Oh, Jennifer, look at you, up again? Don't you ever sleep?
GRANT: Did you have a good evening, Mrs Lombard?
LUCY: Oh, it was work. Why would it be good?
GRANT: Well, I don't know, you seem a little buzzed. I thought maybe you'd met someone.
LUCY: Maybe I did, maybe I didn't. Grant spots the Doctor and Nardole. What are you doing here?
NARDOLE: We could ask you the same question. But it's your apartment, so we probably won't.
DOCTOR: Well, we, we, we, we were worried about you. We wanted to make sure that you were all right, so, er, we followed you.
LUCY: You followed me and got here first?
DOCTOR: Well, that's just a measure of our concern.
NARDOLE: Very concerned.
GRANT: They said they knew you. I let them in.
LUCY: We met tonight. We need to talk, you and me.
GRANT: Oh! Did something happen?
LUCY: Nothing for you to worry your pretty little head about. I'll put her to bed.
GRANT: I can do that.
LUCY: No, it's okay, I want to.
Lucy leaves them.
GRANT: Lombard's her married name. He ran off when the baby came along.
DOCTOR: Lucy. Of course.
High school
Grant is sitting on a bench staring at the floor as the other students go by.
DOCTOR: Hey.
TEEN GRANT: What are you doing here?
DOCTOR: I'm your relief algebra teacher. Thought I'd check in on you and see how you're coping.
TEEN GRANT: Well, it hasn't passed, if that's what you want to know.
DOCTOR: I think that it's a part of your DNA now. It's bonded with you. I'm sorry. Why aren't you looking at me?
TEEN GRANT: I don't want to.
DOCTOR: You're not looking at anyone. Are you shy now? Is that floor really interesting?
TEEN GRANT: I'm not shy. I just can't stop it.
DOCTOR: Can't stop what?
TEEN GRANT: The X-ray vision.
DOCTOR: Oh.
TEEN GRANT: I'm in hell. Naked hell. I just can't look at people.
DOCTOR: It's the gemstone, responding to puberty.
TEEN LUCY: Hey, Grant!
TEEN GRANT: Hey, Lucy!
DOCTOR: You really like her, don't you?
TEEN GRANT: I have X-ray eyes. I like everyone.
DOCTOR: But Lucy is your favourite.
TEEN GRANT: Who says?
The Doctor gently pulls him down from halfway up the wall.
GRANT OC: A couple of years after high school, I ran into her again.
Fire escape
GRANT: She even remembered me.
DOCTOR: Oh, that was lucky.
GRANT: And I was with my best friend at the time, and she couldn't take her eyes off him.
DOCTOR: Okay.
GRANT: Love at first sight.
DOCTOR: Right.
GRANT: Then marriage, then a baby, and then he ran off with someone else.
DOCTOR: Leaving, I suppose, the field open for you to move in.
GRANT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And care for the child she'd had by another man.
GRANT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: So she could keep working and possibly date other friends of yours.
GRANT: Pretty much.
DOCTOR: You tiger. Thank you!
GRANT: Who are you thanking?
DOCTOR: The universe. There's somebody worse at this than me.
Fire engines roar past with a police escort. Grant hands the Doctor his spectacles. Whoosh!
GRANT: Excuse me.
Squeak.
LUCY: This is Mister Huffle. Mister Huffle feels pain.
She squeezes the toy with the tufty hair and it squeals. Oh, how I want one of those.
LUCY: Meet me in the kitchen.
Apartment
Lucy is at the table typing on her laptop as the television on the kitchenette wall reports a major fire in Manhattan. She points to a chair and the Doctor sits obediently.
LUCY: With you in a minute.
On the television, the Ghost flies into the burning building.
LUCY: So, you're from Scotland Yard?
DOCTOR: Yes.
Lucy grabs Mister Huffle, hard.
LUCY: It's fine if you don't tell me your secrets. I intend to keep mine. But don't lie to me.
DOCTOR: Or what?
LUCY: I hurt Mister Huffle.
Huffle re-inflates with a long squeak.
LUCY: I assume you belong to some kind of, I don't know, agency, I don't care which one, and that your current assignment is to investigate Harmony Shoal. Correct?
DOCTOR: No, I was just passing through
Lucy grabs Huffle with both hands.
DOCTOR: Okay, okay. Yes, fine, okay, yes, broadly speaking, yes.
LUCY: What are those brain things?
DOCTOR: I don't know. It's nothing that need concern you.
LUCY: I'm a reporter. That category does not exist. What are they?
DOCTOR: You wouldn't believe me if I told you.
LUCY: No reason not to tell me, then.
Huffle is struggling to re-inflate.
DOCTOR: Those brains, they aren't just brains. They're independent alien life forms.
LUCY: And?
DOCTOR: They migrate from planet to planet, extracting and replacing the central nervous systems of compatible hosts.
LUCY: And?
DOCTOR: Harmony Shoal is a multinational corporation whose true purpose is to extract and replace the brains of key authority figures from around the world, and prepare Earth for full colonisation.
Huffle re-inflates with a quick squeak!
LUCY: Ha.
DOCTOR: You believe me?
LUCY: I don't think you're lying. Slightly different. What has Harmony Shoal got to do with the Ghost?
DOCTOR: Nothing.
LUCY: Ah, so you know who the Ghost really is, then?
DOCTOR: No, I have no idea.
LUCY: Oh, stop it. We just went to a top-secret science research facility apparently run by brains from space, and a flying man with superpowers turns up. Anybody would assume the two were connected, except for somebody who already knew they weren't. So, clearly, you know the Ghost and trust him. Nobody trusts anybody without knowing who they are, so you know who he really is. So now you can tell me. Who is he? Oh, that's interesting. You don't work for an agency, do you?
DOCTOR: Don't I?
LUCY: You're not used to being spoken to like this, which means you don't have a boss or an employer. So why are you investigating Harmony Shoal? What's in it for you?
DOCTOR: I like to keep busy.
LUCY: Why? What happened to you?
DOCTOR: Nothing. Oh, look!
He grabs Huffle and goes to the television. The Ghost is being interviewed.
LUCY: Oh!
GHOST on TV: Because fire prevention is the responsibility of every citizen, so get a smoke detector!
Jennifer cries. Lucy turns away and doesn't see the Ghost check his baby monitor.
GHOST on TV: Sorry, duty calls.
LUCY: Oh, look at him go. I need to know who he is.
GRANT: You're all right. She just needs a change.
LUCY: Oh, it's okay, I'll do it. You're so quick, Grant.
DOCTOR: Oh, yes. He's definitely quick.
The Doctor puts Grant's spectacles back on him.
REPORTER on TV: In less than a minute, this major fire
DOCTOR: Do you have any time off?
GRANT: Sure.

LUCY: Please, it's important.
BOTH: I've got a date. A date?

LUCY: Good girl.
Lucy tucks Jennifer into her cot.
GRANT: Mrs Lombard? You look nice.

Roof

GHOST: I'm not comfortable in restaurants.
LUCY: I suppose you get a lot of stares, dressed like that.
GHOST: Right back at you. Are you sure you're warm enough?

He lights the candle with a snap of his fingers.

Tardis

DOCTOR: Tracking them now. Boom.
NARDOLE: Ha, ha!
Roof
LUCY: So what powers do you have?
GHOST: Well, basic flying, basic super strength.
LUCY: Basic X-ray vision?
GHOST: Yep.
LUCY: Is that ever tempting?

On a green screen zooming in on The Ghost - Subject Located.

Earth orbit

title: Jade
lyrics:
Names of People (Chapter 1) Lyrics                                        CHAPTER ONE

NAMES OF PEOPLE: THE DUCHESSE DE GUERMANTES — SAINT-LOUP AT DONCIÈRES — MME. DE VILLEPARISIS AT HOME — MY GRANDMOTHER’S ILLNESS — BERGOTTE’S ILLNESS — THE DUKE AND THE DOCTOR — DECLINE AND DEATH OF MY GRANDMOTHER

   The twittering of the birds at daybreak sounded insipid to Françoise. Every word uttered by the maids upstairs made her jump; disturbed by all their running about, she kept asking herself what they could be doing. In other words, we had moved. Certainly the servants had made no less noise in the attics of our old home; but she knew them, she had made of their comings and goings familiar events. Now she faced even silence with a strained attention. And as our new neighbourhood appeared to be as quiet as the boulevard on to which we had hitherto looked had been noisy, the song (distinct at a distance, when it was still quite faint, like an orchestralmotif) of a passer-by brought tears to the eyes of a Françoise in exile. And so if I had been tempted to laugh at her in her misery at having to leave a house in which she was ‘so well respected on all sides’ and had packed her trunks with tears, according to the Use of Combray, declaring superior to all possible houses that which had been ours, on the other hand I, who found it as hard to assimilate new as I found it easy to abandon old conditions, I felt myself drawn towards our old servant when I saw that this installation of herself in a building where she had not received from the hall-porter, who did not yet know us, the marks of respect necessary to her moral wellbeing, had brought her positively to the verge of dissolution. She alone could understand what I was feeling; certainly her young footman was not the person to do so; for him, who was as unlike the Combray type as it was possible to conceive, packing up, moving, living in another district, were all like taking a holiday in which the novelty of one’s surroundings gave one the same sense of refreshment as if one had actually travelled; he thought he was in the country; and a cold in the head afforded him, as though he had been sitting in a draughty railway carriage, the delicious sensation of having seen the world; at each fresh sneeze he rejoiced that he had found so smart a place, having always longed to be with people who travelled a lot. And so, without giving him a thought, I went straight to Françoise, who, in return for my having laughed at her tears over a removal which had left me cold, now shewed an icy indifference to my sorrow, but because she shared it. The ‘sensibility’ claimed by neurotic people is matched by their egotism; they cannot abide the flaunting by others of the sufferings to which they pay an ever increasing attention in themselves. Françoise, who would not allow the least of her own ailments to pass unnoticed, if I were in pain would turn her head from me so that I should not have the satisfaction of seeing my sufferings pitied, or so much as observed. It was the same as soon as I tried to speak to her about our new house. Moreover, having been obliged, a day or two later, to return to the house we had just left, to retrieve some clothes which had been overlooked in our removal, while I, as a result of it, had still a ‘temperature,’ and like a boa constrictor that has just swallowed an ox felt myself painfully distended by the sight of a long trunk which my eyes had still to digest, Françoise, with true feminine inconstancy, came back saying that she had really thought she would stifle on our old boulevard, it was so stuffy, that she had found it quite a day’s journey to get there, that never had she seen such stairs, that she would not go back to live there for a king’s ransom, not if you were to offer her millions — a pure hypothesis — and that everything (everything, that is to say, to do with the kitchen and ‘usual offices’) was much better fitted up in the new house. Which, it is high time now that the reader should be told — and told also that we had moved into it because my grandmother, not having been at all well (though we took care to keep this reason from her), was in need of better air — was a flat forming part of the Hôtel de Guermantes

   At the age when a Name, offering us an image of the unknowable which we have poured into its mould, while at the same moment it connotes for us also an existing place, forces us accordingly to identify one with the other to such a point that we set out to seek in a city for a soul which it cannot embody but which we have no longer the power to expel from the sound of its name, it is not only to towns and rivers that names give an individuality, as do allegorical paintings, it is not only the physical universe which they pattern with differences, people with marvels, there is the social universe also; and so every historic house, in town or country, has its lady or its fairy, as every forest has its spirit, as there is a nymph for every stream. Sometimes, hidden in the heart of its name, the fairy is transformed to suit the life of our imagination by which she lives; thus it was that the atmosphere in which Mme. de Guermantes existed in me, after having been for years no more than the shadow cast by a magic lantern slide or the light falling through a painted window, began to let its colours fade when quite other dreams impregnated it with the bubbling coolness of her flowing streams

   And yet the fairy must perish if we come in contact with the real person to whom her name corresponds, for that person the name then begins to reflect, and she has in her nothing of the fairy; the fairy may revive if we remove ourself from the person, but if we remain in her presence the fairy definitely dies and with her the name, as happened to the family of Lusignan, which was fated to become extinct on the day when the fairy Mélusine should disappear. Then the Name, beneath our successive ‘restorations’ of which we may end by finding, as their original, the beautiful portrait of a strange lady whom we are never to meet, is nothing more than the mere photograph, for identification, to which we refer in order to decide whether we know, whether or not we ought to bow to a person who passes us in the street. But let a sensation from a bygone year — like those recording instruments which preserve the sound and the manner of the various artists who have sung or played into them — enable our memory to make us hear that name with the particular ring with which it then sounded in our ears, then, while the name itself has apparently not changed, we feel the distance that separates the dreams which at different times its same syllables have meant to us. For a moment, from the clear echo of its warbling in some distant spring, we can extract, as from the little tubes which we use in painting, the exact, forgotten, mysterious, fresh tint of the days which we had believed ourself to be recalling, when, like a bad painter, we were giving to the whole of our past, spread out on the same canvas, the tones, conventional and all alike, of our unprompted memory. Whereas on the contrary, each of the moments that composed it employed, for an original creation, in a matchless harmony, the colour of those days which we no longer know, and which, for that matter, will still suddenly enrapture me if by any chance the name ‘Guermantes,’ resuming for a moment, after all these years, the sound, so different from its sound to-day, which it had for me on the day of Mile. Percepied’s marriage, brings back to me that mauve — so delicate, almost too bright, too new — with which the billowy scarf of the young Duchess glowed, and, like two periwinkle flowers, growing beyond reach and blossoming now again, her two eyes, sunlit with an azure smile. And the name Guermantes of those days is also like one of those little balloons which have been filled wilh oxygen, or some such gas; when I come to explode it, to make it emit what it contains, I breathe the air of the Combray of that year, of that day, mingled with a fragrance of hawthorn blossom blown by the wind from the corner of the square, harbinger of rain, which now sent the sun packing, now let him spread himself over the red woollen carpet to the sacristy, steeping it in a bright geranium scarlet, with that, so to speak, Wagnerian harmony in its gaiety which makes the wedding service always impressive. But even apart from rare moments such as these, in which suddenly we feel the original entity quiver and resume its form, carve itself out of the syllables now soundless, dead; if, in the giddy rush of daily life, in which they serve only the most practical purposes, names have lost all their colour, like a prismatic top that spins too quickly and seems only grey, when, on the other hand, in our musings we reflect, we seek, so as to return to the past, to slacken, to suspend the perpetual motion by which we are borne alcng, gradually we see once more appear, side by side, but entirely distinct from one another, the tints which in the course of our existence have been successively presented to us by a single name

   What form was assumed in my mind by this name Guermantes when my first nurse — knowing no more, probably, than I know to-day in whose honour it had been composed — sang me to sleep with that old ditty, Gloire à la Marquise de Guermantes, or when, some years later, the veteran Maréchal de Guermantes, making my nursery-maid’s bosom swell with pride, stopped in the Champs-Elysées to remark: “A fine child that!” and gave me a chocolate drop from his comfit-box, I cannot, of course, now say. Those years of my earliest childhood are no longer a part of myself; they are external to me; I can learn nothing of them save as we learn things that happened before we were born — from the accounts given me by other people. But more recently I find in the period of that name’s occupation of me seven or eight different shapes which it has successively assumed; the earliest were the most beautiful; gradually my musings, forced by reality to abandon a position that was no longer tenable, established themselves anew in one slightly less advanced until they were obliged to retire still farther. And, with Mme. de Guermantes, was transformed simultaneously her dwelling, itself also the offspring of that name, fertilised from year to year by some word or other that came to my ears and modulated the tone of my musings; that dwelling of hers reflected them in its very stones, which had turned to mirrors, like the surface of a cloud or of a lake.
